datafield.subfield: Inside front cover: Presented by / (I/J) Lee Doctors Commons / -->reframed. August 1835. no 12/93; H. Wilmut Brixton / 1862; 1037 caxx / myaxx / [circled_"31"]; Biblia Liber Prophetarum / Ms. Pars Juee. XIV / (1380 circa) ; (2 ex libris). Front cover, ex libris: bend dexter azure over field with dual fess in the first and fourth quarters, anchored chevron surrounded by 3 diamonds, in the second and third quarter. Supported above by bridled bear passant (dexter) and equine crest/bust showing fleur. (motto:) verum atque decens. (Also below read with a loop and magnifying glass) "_\hitlow SeYork 81." Front cover ex libris: Amadei Svajer / halved field showing arborial dexter and rampant lion sinister, crowned with helm and rampant lion. Front flyleaf recto: No. 109; Burgess Ms. 31; 25; 19; No. 4; 12/93. Rear cover: Pasted stamp with blue border: 1; 90069; 1200/-; 950/- . Rear flyleaf verso: C M Jr.
Item cataloged from existing description by C. Pierce and J. Fox, and in hand by Erika Milo and Ian Scott, July/August 2018.
All requests for permission to quote or publish from manuscripts must be submitted in writing to the Head of Special Collections & University Archives.

This is a vulgate translation of the minor prophets, including prologues. of special interest in that it exemplifies the type of script which influenced Gutenburg. "The date, "circa 1380," is given in a note on the inside cover, confirmed by a well-known palaeographer. In the 14th century there was a return from the close-packed text, executed with precision of the 13th century, to the amplitude of the 12th century. Bibles and liturgical works were built on a large scale. The letters were more in uniform than those seen in our example of the 12th century, and lacked the flexible individuality of the special scribe. "An air of softness pervades the writing" says E. Maude Thompson, but the effect in "Liber Prophetarum" is one of noble simplicity. One notes a resemblance between this script and the printed text of Gutenburg's 36-line Bible. The difference is in the more rounded letter and in the uncrowned line of this script. There is softness, but it is a hoppy mean between the extreme pointed text found in Gutenburg's Bible and the rounded text of later times. This script is distinctly and beautifully Gothic."
Collation: folio in quires of 8 (except last 3). One leaf blank removed between Isaiah and Jeremiah, with no loss to the text. Enclosed catchwords, lower corner of last page. Penciled folio numbers.

Layout: 2 columns of 34 lines at 8 mm, on writing area 265 x 160 mm. Each interior column width is 73 mm, and exterior is 74 mm. Central margin is 21.5 mm. Book titles above text, Roman chapter numerals, capital strokes, and long introductory headings, all in red. Ruling by lead point and pricking visible.
Script: Gothic minuscule textura with a 1.5 mm width nib.
Decoration: Book initials in red and blue, 5-6 lines high. Initials in red or blue with alternate red or blue tracery, 2 lines high.

Binding: Polished calf over paper board; spine shows 6 raised bands (though 7 exposed); front cover fully disconnected; rear cover partially disconnected. Gilt medallion of a Bishop has been obliterated from each cover.
Shelfmark: Eugene, OR, Special Collections and University Archives, University of Oregon, MS 031.

Formatted Content Note: ff1-47 Ysaias; ff48-104 Iherias, ff105-109 verba baruch; ff109-111 Epl'a ihemie; ff. 112-160 Ezechiel; ff161-181 Daniel; ff182-189 Osee; ff189-192 Iohel; ff192-197 Amos; f198 Abdias; ff 199-200 Ionas; ff201-205 Micheas; ff205-207 Naum; ff208-211 Abacuc; ff211-213 Sophonias; ff214-215 Aggeus; ff216-223 Zacharias, ff 224-226 Malachias.
